major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Notice of Recording
Urban Analysis and Simulation Fall 2024
A range of special topics within visual and digital media that include course offerings in parametric design and scripting, advanced visualization, interaction design, and digital fabrication.
The urban realm is a complex territory.

In urban realms, we are often forces to ask ourselves what our priorities are, a question that become more and more relevant as populations move to urban centers, and our understanding of the role cities play in broader contexts grows.
With competing agendas, budding ideas, and critical decisions all at play, designers are turning to data, analysis, and simulation to make more informed decisions and test new ideas.
This course will introduce students to tools, methodologies, and concepts that will allow them to pursue analysis informed investigations of topics of interest relating to the expanded urban realm.

The course will begin at a broader scale looking at regional data driven mapping using GIS, before moving towards site-finding exercises and scenario testing using simulation, analysis, and optimization in a grasshopper environment.

course_name: ARCH520 - Special Topics in Urbanism and Landscape (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Notice of Recording
Cultivated Landscapes in World Cinema Fall 2024
A range of special topics courses within urbanism and landscape.

The idea of the landscape develops in history, but also in the individual, through the effects of time and space joined together in the rhythm of lines and surfaces that human beings know how to compose almost instinctively”.

Let us remember that the first civilizations arose on the banks of rivers, and that in the ancient world the river was not only the source of fertile land and nourishment, and the place of gathering, but also the artery of movement and transport, and that water’s symbolic role in the origin and ritual renewal of life originates in the ecology of the river.
We view diverse films in which natural and cultural landscapes play a major, decisive role in the situations and scenarios experienced by the characters.
We then interpret, and discuss to reflect the real world that underlies these artworks, facilitate raising questions, and uncover issues pertinent to our cultural and natural worlds.
Then, I give a slide lecture introduction to watching the next film, to give you a sense of what to look for and introduce connected themes.
Cultural history and landscape cinema
In this course, we study films to analyze landscape’s coding of cultural meaning and symbolism.
Just as we project our minds into our situations, and reflect our environments, we explore how cultures embed values in landscapes and spatial depths.
In the fiction films and readings for this course, landscape and its cultural coding plays a significant role in the drama.

The lab-style, workshop core of this course involves building up visual and textual literacy, practice intended to foster and refine skills in analysis of cultural artifacts, researching with both primary and secondary sources, and written expression and communication.
Geographer Donald Meinig (1976) described landscape as the union of the physical and the psychological: “composed not only of what lies before our eyes but what lies within our heads.”
It reflects prior experience as well as prevailing cultural, social, and economic values.
Landscapes express, in addition to their own biophysical makeup, the character of a society as it has evolved over an extended period of time.
The course viewings expose the cultural contents of landscapes via dramatizations of processes, movement, conflict and enactments in movies and related media, space-time artifacts.

These complex materials facilitate our discussion of contemporary ideas and issues, relating people and other living things to places and geological and atmospheric realities, topics including colonialism and social power, war, modernity, indigeneity and identity, sacred sites and religious practices, environmentalism, wilderness and the sublime, the journey, subjectivism, nationalism, sense of place, encounter, strangeness and surreality, fate and destiny, utopias/dystopias, the noble savage, representation, horror and formlessness, etc.

As a workshop course in research and writing to create and refine skills in analysis of cultural artifacts and written communication, your learning process requires initiative and critical thinking, and is self-directed, resourceful, responsive, and iterative.
One class (Troll Hunter) will be devoted to examining the idea of sustainability through a cultural and social lens, and the role that architecture, the arts, and landscape might play.
Conceptual vocabulary list — highlight words in your notes

Each of you will choose one of our class films as an inspirational model, and visually tell a story for a place-based or site-based story in the landscape of your choice, assembled with elements that provide evidence of your understanding of landscapes as material, symbolic, temporal, spatial, and complex, and the course materials.
Your basic practice involves building these study habits:
Note thematic keywords on your “conceptual vocabulary” list to test and use in your Boolean (multi-word) searches.
Each person will verbally communicate their insights.
What elements in the film caught your eye / interest while watching?
How can you make a link between your observation of the film as a primary source to your secondary sources?
What feeling(s) did the film elicit in you?
Make an effort to respond to someone else’s comments and then create a link to your own ideas, rather than everyone starting their own isolated topic.
In this course, a few short readings in PDF format will be posted in the “Files” of our Teams channel.

course_name: ARCH540 - Special Topics in Architectural History and Theory (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: A range of special topics courses within cultural and architectural history, theory, and criticism.
Gieseking argues for the fundamental impacts of spatial imagery and mapping on the creation of perceived, conceived and lived experiences of space.

The straightening and assimilation of queer culture into more mainstream heteronormative society illustrates the significance of formulating spatial narratives of past, present, and future to protect the histories of resiliency that the community has overcome through the production of queer space.

Drawing inspiration from the concept of geographical imagination, whether imagined or real, these narratives demonstrate the potential to validate one’s characterization of space and how it may also shape practices, behaviors, and social structures.
Forms of cartographic documentation, drawing, and writing will be tools to recount and illustrate new and old narratives to form a constellation of (non)fictions across the City of Toronto.

By the end of the semester, digital narratives will archive, present, and hypothesize the nuances of individual queer experiences to reveal collective queer resilience as it pertains to the socio-cultural-economic structures within the City.
The seminars will allow groups to specialize in specific themes that encompass socio-cultural-spatial research through text and drawing.

This course explores ethical issues in biomedical engineering practice, including professional ethics, medical ethics, the ethics of human and animal subject use in biomedical research, and the impact of biomedical engineering solutions on society and the environment.

This course aims to guide students in understanding the complex relationships between design, biomedical technologies and society and to appreciate how such an understanding can improve design outcomes from the user, community, national, and global perspectives.

Identify and evaluate considerations that influence ethical decisions regarding design, modification, and use of biomedical technologies, and the ethical concepts and arguments relevant to these practices (6 a, b, c; 7 a, b; 10 a, b, c);
Create rational solutions to ethical situations of concern related to biomedical engineering (6, 7);
Demonstrate an understanding of the social responsibilities of biomedical engineers (8 a, b);
Describe the importance of social factors affecting development, uptake, and impact of biomedical technologies on society in both developed and developing countries (7, 8).

This course builds students' technical competencies in life cycle assessment (LCA) and in critical analysis of products' environmental impacts through an understanding of life cycle management.

The course will consider methods of creating a culture of integrity; examine and evaluate methods such as due-diligence processes, risk assessment, sustainability assessment to integrate responsibility into day-to-day business positions; and evaluate social and sustainability reports; evaluate methods to determine the link between responsibility and increased profitability and benchmark responsibility in different business sectors including non-profit organizations.
This course is an examination of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) in theory and practice.
Students will investigate the ways in which global – but also local – ‘firms’ pursue business processes in socially and environmentally responsible ways.

The course adopts an applied, forward-looking, and solutions-oriented perspective, and aims to equip upper-level students with the critical thinking and reflective management practice skills necessary to respond effectively to the widespread CSR challenges facing managers today.

Given the breadth of material encompassed within the scope of CSR, students will initially be exposed to a subset of CSR topics through a series of traditional lectures as well as guest speakers, peer learning, and self-led learning.

Systems Assignment

In this course, we delve into analytical approaches for defining and solving environmental and resource issues, emphasizing the importance of understanding these problems within their broader contexts.
This assignment is designed to enhance your grasp of systems thinking—a crucial skill for addressing complex environmental challenges.

By engaging with a case study, you will explore the intricate web of factors that contribute to environmental issues, identify key nodes within these systems, and develop a systems map to visualize these connections.
Defining foundational concepts: You will apply systems thinking and sustainability principles to real-world environmental problems.
Identifying links between social and ecological aspects: Your case study will highlight the interconnectedness of social and ecological factors, both locally and globally.
Examining and evaluating research: You will critically analyze complex environmental problems through your case study, enhancing your research skills.
Evaluating sources of information: By sourcing information from mainstream media and peer-reviewed journals, you will develop information literacy and critical thinking skills.
Four smaller, scaffolded assignments make up this larger Systems Assignment.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Notice of Recording
This course examines environmental security and the political ecology of violence.
War, colonialism, and other forms of social conflict are discussed as both drivers and consequences of environmental change including the extraction, consumption, and depletion of resources.
Topics may include nuclear war and emerging technologies as existential threats to humanity; (neo) environmental determinism; eco-fascism and totalitarianism; and eco-terrorism.

Hopeful insights for transitioning towards sustainability are drawn from rapid societal mobilization and transformation during wartimes and the role of the environment and environmentalism in peacebuilding.
To develop an analysis of war and violence as a central socio-ecological process (i.e., violence and socio-ecological change as a dialectical relationship).

To apprentice our social, emotional and analytical skills as learners and civic participants both inside and outside the classroom (e.g., as critically informed discussants, inquisitive and generous listeners, and civically-engaged inhabitants who are reflexive of the power relations inherent in any communicative space).
List the socio-ecological impacts of militaries and violent conflict including direct and indirect costs as well as opportunity costs;
Describe how militaries use and transform the environment strategically and how environmental politics and environmental change shape militaries and military strategy;
Evaluate critiques of colonialism and capitalism as inherently violent socio-ecological processes;

Compare and critique dominant theoretical paradigms for understanding the relationship between environmental change and violent conflict (i.e., neo-Malthusian scarcity hypotheses; neoclassical abundance or “resource curse” hypotheses; and political-ecological distributional and contextual hypotheses);
and for states of nature and human nature;
Critically analyze “eco-terrorism” as a political-legal construction and activist strategy (i.e., direct action);
Appraise past rapid societal transformations during wartime to inspire policies for addressing today’s pressing socio-ecological crises;
Facilitate small group meetings and discussions and strengthen a sense of collective responsibility;
Improve skills for critical synthesis and efficient reading of academic texts.

It is the knowledge that people have of each other, their concern for each other, their trust in each other, the freedom with which they come and go among themselves.”
ERS 253 explores communities and sustainability as a useful pairing of ideas and practices.

This will involve applying a broad and critically advanced approach to community and sustainability (plus a few closely related concepts, including complexity and engagement in governance and decision making, as key factors for attention); and aiming to identify the practical implications, including for particular undertakings that aim to contribute to lasting wellbeing at the community scale.
There are cultural, occupational, ideological and interest-based communities, among others.

The course work will include development and application of tools to build an integrated understanding of communities, sustainability and engagement and to expand this understanding in discussions about issues and actions in a variety of particular areas of concern and opportunity (food systems, growth, decline, economic greening, ecosystems, etc.).

Perhaps most importantly, each participant will integrate the broad insights, specify them for the particular context of a community of her or his choice, and apply the results in the conception and evaluation of a sustainability-enhancing undertaking in that community.
The latter half is focused on application – we will return to many of the concepts in our readings and apply them to real-world cases with exciting guest speakers.

Continuing from concepts developed in ERS215, this course places more emphasis on case studies and projects by students.

The course provides a synthesis of ecological, physical, economic, socio-cultural, and institutional concerns, as well as experience in the use of impact assessment methodologies and approaches, as a key element in achieving more informed and responsible decision making.
View requirements for ERS 315
Tutorial work will be semi-directed and self-guided.
The concepts introduced in ERS 215 and 315 are applied to a broader range of pursuits in ERS 415, the next course in the assessment series.
Recommend and implement tools and frameworks for managing impacts.
Quntify impact magnitude and significance before and after impact management.

Over the past half century Environmental and Sustainability Assessment has evolved from seeking to minimize the short-term and localized negative biophysical impacts of certain development projects to considerations of net benefit to both the environment and the people that it supports including future generations.

As such, the exercise of EA brings you face to face with questions of the sustainability of our actions including cumulative effects, trade-offs and appropriate temporal, spatial and contextual considerations.
Outcome 2: Define and articulate core skills and areas of knowledge relating to SERS’ areas of strength
Environmental and sustainability assessment are explicitly listed as areas in which we seek to develop skills and depth of understanding in SERS students.

Outcome 3: Understand and work within, between and across disciplines and ways of knowing Environmental and sustainability assessment are by their very nature inter- and transdisciplinary pursuits because they require the engagement of a broad range of disciplinary expertise and must by law engage all parties that might be impacted by a development and explicitly including Indigenous Peoples and ways of knowing.
Outcome 4: Mobilize skills and knowledge to contribute to better understandings, diagnoses and solutions for environmental and sustainability challenges and opportunities

Ways of establishing the condition of the environment and how it is changing (i.e., monitoring), making predictions about how a new development will impact the environment including its peoples and managing those impacts to reduce them if they are negative and maximize them if they are positive are all aspects of environmental and sustainability assessment that we discuss in this course.

Outcome 5: Work collaboratively and effectively with people and organizations affected by orresponsible for addressing environmental and sustainability challenges and opportunities Collaboration is an essential skill to master in environmental and sustainability assessment work.
For this reason this course brings in working professionals to discuss their experiences in particular EA case studies.
The ability to write and speak clearly about complex and often emotionally charged issues is an essential skill in EA work.
Through readings and the guest speakers who share their knowledge in this course you will be exposed to some great communication in the area of environmental and sustainability assessment.

course_name: ERS454 - Parks and Protected Areas: Issues and Trends (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: ERS 454
ERS 454:
View requirements for ERS 454
This course explores the critical roles parks and protected areas play in the sustainability of human societies and the natural world.

Parks and protected areas, both nationally and internationally, are set aside to achieve a range of public policy outcomes including the conservation of biodiversity, ecological integrity, sustainable ecosystems, social well being and economic benefits.

The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) classification system and conservation guidelines will be used as the basis for comparative analysis and the identification of policy objectives related to protected lands and waters.

The relationship of parks and protected areas to environmental trends such as climate change, water and food security, economic development and biological diversity will be examined in the Canadian and international contexts.

In addition, the role of parks and protected areas as an element of Canadian identity will be considered based on shifting public priorities related to environmental protection and socio-economic well being.
Government decisions to set aside lands and waters for conservation are policy choices to conserve rather than develop or degrade ecological and natural resources.
These decisions create socio-ecological systems and are often controversial, calling into question societal values and valuation related to the natural world.
The course considers the societal values associated with conservation and will use case studies to examine how and why natural resources are protected through establishment processes.

The question of whether there is a fundamentally irreconcilable tension between policies of protection and use of parks and protected areas will be considered, as well as the influence that political priorities and preferences play in the policy emphasis affecting management of conservation lands and waters.

The role of shifting demographics related to government decisions to establish parks and protected areas, and the types of programs, services and opportunities for conservation and public use will be considered in the context of past, current and emerging trends and public policy choices.

•Understand and evaluate the diverse and complex public policy dynamics related to the establishment of parks and protected areas, and the management of parks and protected areas systems in Canada, and internationally.

•Explore key issues and trends related to parks and protected areas to, and be able to assess the effectiveness of legislation, public policy and strategies to address the long-term sustainability of systems protected lands and waters.

•Understand and apply knowledge of the roles and benefits of parks and protected areas in the broader context of environmental sustainability at the national and international scales and understand the role of parks and protected areas in achieving a range of public policy outcomes.

The course provides an overview of human ecological aspects of environmental studies from an inter-cultural and global perspective, and offers an integrative framework for understanding them.
This first-year course introduces the field of environmental studies, exploring the relationships and interactions between humans and their natural, social, and built environments.
Explore the variety of demographic, economic, and socio-cultural/ethical processes underlying human interaction with the natural world;
Develop an understanding of the planetary systems and processes that have been disturbed by human activity and contribute to the environmental challenges that we face today;
These environmental challenges will be studied at the global, national and local levels, and the complexity and interconnectedness of these various challenges are examined; and
Examine key planning and management approaches, concepts, and frameworks that may be useful for responding to environmental challenges.
The course promotes acquisition of core environmental knowledge (concepts, principles, practices) from the perspectives of social sciences, environmental sciences, and management.
Articulate key perspectives on the demographic, economic, and socio-cultural/ethical processes that have influenced human interactions with the environment.
Situate their own values and perspectives of key drivers of environmental degradation within the context of other perspectives.
Comprehend the process of biodiversity, the movement of energy through ecosystems and the impacts of disruptions on ecosystems.
Explain the key storage pools and movements between storage pools for identified biogeochemical cycles and the impact of disruptions to these cycles.
Appreciate the causes and implications of key environmental challenges, including climate change and air pollution, agriculture, waste management, energy, and oceans and fisheries.
Identify and assess the pros and cons of potential solutions to key environmental challenges.
Apply planning and management concepts and frameworks to key environmental issues.
Utilize basic terminology and concepts as applied in the field of environmental studies.
Application skills: Through applying concepts, approaches, and frameworks to various case studies.

course_name: ENVS201 - Introduction to Canadian Environmental Law (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Introduction to Canadian Environmental Law Fall 2024
Introduction to the basic legal framework that regulates the natural environment in Canada.
The course provides students with an understanding of the foundational legal institutions in Canada and their respective roles in environmental regulation.
The course includes both public and private law approaches to environmental regulation, and covers the principal regulatory tools used to protect the environment.
View requirements for ENVS 201

In particular, students will be able to identify and describe the basic structural features of the Canadian legal system and their relationship to the environment; to differentiate and apply legal causes of action that provide remedies to those impacted from environmental harm caused by others; and to describe and apply the legal basis for regulatory and criminal action against polluters.

By the end of the course students should be able identify and classify legal issues within increasingly complex fact patterns; interpret cases and legislation, with an emphasis on identifying rules and principles; and to apply abstract legal rules/principles to factual situations to generate legal conclusions.

As clear, objective communication is a crucial skill to providing legal and policy advice, students will engage in a number of written exercises oriented towards improving professional written communication skills.

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Ecological Economics Winter 2025
The links between economics, systems and the natural environment will be explored and future directions examined.
View requirements for ENVS 220
This course provides an engaging introduction to ecological economics, framed through the lens of Doughnut Economics by Kate Raworth.

Together, we will explore how ecological economics challenges the assumptions of conventional economics and expands its scope to address the pressing challenges of sustainability, equity, and planetary boundaries.
Using the Doughnut model as a central guide, we will examine the concept of a “safe and just space for humanity” and the interplay between social foundations and ecological ceilings.
Rethinking Growth: Investigating the limits of economic growth, the role of natural resources, and critiquing growth-centric paradigms.

Redefining Progress: We will compare conventional measures like GDP with alternative metrics such as ecological footprints, planetary boundaries, and well-being and indices of human to assess their relevance in shaping policy and decision-making.
Special attention will be given to the intersection of ecological economics with issues like climate justice, social equity, and intergenerational ethics.
Globalization and Local Action: Understanding the environmental implications of globalization and the role of local communities in driving sustainable change.
Understand and Differentiate: Explain the foundational principles of ecological economics and how they contrast with conventional economic theories and environmental/resource economics.
Articulate the core concepts of the Doughnut Economics framework, including social foundations and ecological ceilings.
Critique growth-centric economic models from ecological, social, and ethical perspectives.

Apply Analytical Tools: Analyze policy options like taxes, subsidies, quotas, and emissions trading through both economic and ecological lenses, considering their potential impacts on sustainability and equity.
Use systems-thinking approaches to apply Doughnut Economics principles to real-world challenges in areas such as energy, food systems, or urban planning.
Discuss the ethical dimensions of economic policies, including intergenerational equity and climate justice.

course_name: ENVS310 - Future Cities: Integrating Future Thinking into Urban Decisions (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Future Cities: Integrating Future Thinking into Urban Decisions Fall 2024
View requirements for ENVS 310

Concepts like eco-cities—centers of sustainability that prioritize green spaces, renewable energy, and eco-friendly architecture such as green roofs and vertical farms—offer hopeful visions of a sustainable tomorrow.

Meanwhile, smart cities promise a future where interconnected sensors and advanced data analytics streamline everything from traffic flow to energy consumption, turning urban living into an optimized, efficient ecosystem.
In this module, we will critically examine how these ideas are shaped by specific political, cultural, and economic interests, reflecting particular values and worldviews.
Understanding the forces behind these visions will empower you to engage with them more critically and think more deeply about the kind of future you want to help shape.
2. Analyze the reciprocal relationship between future visions and city development processes, and how each shapes the other;
3. Examine the inequalities present in the creation and representation of urban imaginaries;
Apply tools and methods to actively participate in the co-creation of equitable and sustainable future cities

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: ncraik@uwaterloo.ca

The course examines the historical development of the constitutional relationship between the Crown (the Canadian and provincial governments) and Indigenous Peoples, and the current impact of this constitutional relationship on the development of resources in Canada.

The course examines the historical development of the constitutional relationship between the Crown (the Canadian and provincial governments) and Aboriginal peoples, and its current impact on the development of resources in Canada.

Particular focus will be paid to the judicial development of Aboriginal rights and Aboriginal title, the duty to consult and accommodate Aboriginal peoples in the context of resource development and the future trajectory of the relationship between the Crown, Aboriginal peoples, and resource developers.

topics: This course takes a case study approach to examining the role of the art object as a means of communication within the history of visual culture.
We might think of the themes as case studies.
We will also focus with equal intensity on the properties of visuality, i.e. how do images and objects communicate effectively?

The primary goals of the course are to recognize the significant role visual culture plays in human history and human societies AND to develop the analytical skills and vocabulary to discuss images and objects within that context.

Be introduced to, and develop basic research skills, for the study of visual images and objects by: using a range of resources and recognizing the parameters and properties of each (websites, newspapers, academic texts, interviews, films, etc.), and learning to access resources through the UW Library and other providers and platforms

Tracing the histories, aesthetics and politics of digital art, students will critically examine the emergence of digital technologies, and their roles in transforming artistic practices, modes of production, and integration across media disciplines.

Through both chronological and thematic approaches, students will engage with theoretical readings, analyze historical and contemporary case studies in art and digital spaces in everyday life, and create studio-based projects that respond to or critique digital and mediated cultures.

By the end of the course, students will have developed both a historical understanding and practical fluency in the ways digital art shapes, and is shaped by, cultural and technological transformations.

topics: V. Dusaillant-Fernandes
vcdusaillantfernandes@uwaterloo.ca
A study of selected works by women writers in France from the Middle Ages to the 21st-century.
The course will focus on the literary features of these works and on their value as reflections of the position of women in French society throughout the period.

À travers l'analyse, la discussion, l'évaluation en classe et les travaux écrits sur des œuvres sélectionnées, ce cours approfondira les connaissances des étudiant.e.s sur les différents genres et les introduira aux concepts théoriques pertinents pour élucider ces œuvres.
